sourceDesc.p: This is the file that describes the reflexes of ġ

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is found in some lexical items but it is not the main realization of ġ
The feature does´t have a specific section. The value is taken from the inventory of consonants phonemes
The feature does´t have a specific section. The value is taken from the inventory of consonants phonemes
The feature does´t have a specific section. The value is taken from the inventory of consonants phonemes
The feature does´t have a specific section. The value is taken from the inventory of consonants phonemes
The feature does´t have a specific section. The value is taken from the inventory of consonants phonemes
in contact with voicless consonants
all words with the root š-ġ-l

Information deduced from an example, not explicitly stated in the source.
Sometimes ġ turns into h for example in the root ġ-r-' i.e. yihra' meaning it (will) sink
Information deduced from an example, not explicitly stated in the source.
Information deduced from an example, not explicitly stated in the source.
Deduced from examples
More educated speakers tend to prefer the standard realization ġ, ġāli ("expensive").
Ġayn is rarely retained as ġ, only few cases of literate speakers in literary contexts.
very few instances of ʕ
ġ > x: only with verb 'to wash': xsəl
sometimes labialized
Maltese orthography: xoghol
Some times it may be realised as /ḥ/, e.g. ḥasel `to wash´
/ġ/ is attested only among certain speakers (mainly in the west, southwest, and northwest) when it is not geminated
/ġ/ and /q/ have merged, being realized as [q] by the other Ḥassāniyya speakers (central, eastern, and northeastern Mauretania, Mali, and Algeria)
ġ > x before the sibilants s and t: nəxsəl 'i wash'; also often labialized
deduced from texts
In the verb "to want" *ġ is often reflected as glottal stop /ʔ/ which in turn can eventually be dropped. Examples: bġīt > bʔīt > bīt nʕīš “I want to live” (Guerrero 2016:277)
sometimes ġ > x (ḫ), e.g.: ḫsél 'to wash'
/ġ/ > /ʕ/ frequent, e.g. ġir > ġa > ʕa
Women pronounce ġ sometimes as x: xsəl 'to wash'
in free variation with q (Behnstedt 2016:11)
in free variation with ġ (Behnstedt 2016:11)
in free variation with q (Behnstedt 2016:11)
in free variation with ġ (Behnstedt 2016:11)
/ġ/ before /r/ is pronounced ʕ
Cf. Vanhove 1995:146.
Cf. Vanhove 1995:146.
Cf. Vanhove 1995:146; it is only rarely used among young people, but more by elderly speakers.
